title: الاشْتِغَالُ
description: Learn about الاشتغال, a grammatical construction where a verb is 'occupied' with a pronoun while its logical object appears earlier in the sentence.

notes.title: What is الاشتغال?
content: الاشتغال (Occupation) is a grammatical phenomenon where a noun appears before a verb, and the verb is 'occupied' with a pronoun that refers back to that noun.
For example: زَيْدًا ضَرَبْتُهُ (Zaid, I hit him). Here, زيدًا appears before the verb ضربته, and the ه in ضربته refers back to زيد.
The verb is said to be 'occupied' (مشغول) with the pronoun, preventing it from directly governing the fronted noun. This raises the question: what governs the fronted noun?
keyPoints: The noun (المشغول عنه) appears before the verb
The verb contains a pronoun referring to that noun
The verb is 'occupied' with governing the pronoun
The fronted noun needs a grammatical explanation

notes.title: Grammatical Analysis
content: There are two main views on parsing the fronted noun in الاشتغال. The Basrans say it is منصوب بفعل محذوف (accusative by a deleted verb).
According to this view, زَيْدًا ضَرَبْتُهُ is originally: ضَرَبْتُ زَيْدًا ضَرَبْتُهُ, with the first verb deleted to avoid repetition.
The Kufans allow the noun to be governed by the visible verb despite the pronoun. Both analyses yield the same surface form but differ in underlying structure.
keyPoints: البصريون: The noun is governed by a deleted verb
The deleted verb is understood from the visible one
The visible verb governs only the pronoun
This analysis maintains the principle: one verb, one object

examples.english: Zaid I hit him = I hit Zaid, I hit him (deleted verb analysis)

notes.title: Cases of Obligatory and Preferred Accusative
content: The fronted noun must be accusative (منصوب) when it follows particles that require a verb after them, such as أدوات الشرط (conditional particles) or أدوات التحضيض (urging particles).
The accusative is preferred (but not obligatory) when the context suggests action, such as answering a question like 'What did you do?'
In neutral contexts, both nominative (as مبتدأ) and accusative (by a deleted verb) are acceptable.
keyPoints: وجوب النصب: After إنْ، هَلَّا، أَلَّا، لَوْلَا (urging)
رجحان النصب: When answering 'what did you do?'
The context determines the preferred case
After interrogative أَ, either case is acceptable

examples.english: If you meet Zaid, honor him (obligatory accusative)
Why didn't you fulfill the duty? (obligatory accusative)
What did you do? The lesson, I wrote it (preferred accusative)
Did you hit Zaid or Amr? (accusative preferred)

notes.title: Cases of Obligatory and Preferred Nominative
content: The fronted noun must be nominative (مرفوع) as a مبتدأ when the verb cannot govern it, such as when the verb is جامد (non-derived) or when there is a barrier between them.
The nominative is preferred when the context suggests description rather than action, such as answering 'Who is the student?'
When إذا الفجائية (sudden إذا) precedes the noun, nominative is obligatory as it can only introduce مبتدأ.
keyPoints: وجوب الرفع: When verb cannot govern (جامد or barrier)
رجحان الرفع: When answering 'who is X?'
The noun becomes مبتدأ and the verbal sentence is its خبر

examples.english: Zaid, what an excellent man he is (obligatory nominative)
I went out, and suddenly Zaid - Amr was hitting him
Who is the winner? Zaid, I rewarded him (preferred nominative)
The student, I knew him to be diligent

exercises.answer: occupation (verb occupied with pronoun while logical object is fronted)
the element the verb is occupied from (the fronted noun)
